cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphitization alters the microstructure of carbon steels after long-term operation, degrading their mechanical properties.

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: operation in the 800°F to 1100°F (427°C to 593°C) range
qualifiers.CausalHint: that may cause a loss in strength, ductility, and/or creep resistance

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphitization alters the microstructure of 0.5Mo steels during long-term high-temperature operation.

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: operation in the 800°F to 1100°F (427°C to 593°C) range
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DamageType: loss in strength, ductility, and/or creep resistance

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphitization corresponds to decomposition of carbide phases into graphite nodules, effectively producing graphite nodules in the steel.
remarks: Carbide phases are not an explicit entity; relation framed between graphitization and graphite nodules to preserve transformation context.

args.canonical_rel_desc: A process or condition changes the microstructure of a material or alloy (e.g., phase distribution, morphology, or microstructural constituents).
args.justification: Both relations describe graphitization changing the microstructure of different steels under long-term high-temperature operation; they share the same direction (process → material) and semantic meaning of microstructural alteration.

args.canonical_rel_desc: A process or transformation leads to the formation of a specific microstructural constituent or feature within a material (e.g., graphite nodules, carbides, precipitates).
args.justification: This relation specifically captures that graphitization produces/creates graphite nodules as microstructural features in the steel, which is more precise than a generic 'produces' predicate.

All three relations describe how the graphitization process changes or generates microstructural features in steels (altering existing microstructure or forming graphite nodules), so they belong to the same broader class of microstructural transformation relations.

Each relation expresses that a process (graphitization) modifies the state of a material by changing its microstructure or forming new microstructural constituents, fitting a broad modification/change-of-state dimension rather than simple association or identity.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: A process or condition changes the microstructure of a material or alloy (e.g., phase distribution, morphology, or microstructural constituents).
executed_decisions.justification: Both relations describe graphitization changing the microstructure of different steels under long-term high-temperature operation; they share the same direction (process → material) and semantic meaning of microstructural alteration.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: A process or transformation leads to the formation of a specific microstructural constituent or feature within a material (e.g., graphite nodules, carbides, precipitates).
executed_decisions.justification: This relation specifically captures that graphitization produces/creates graphite nodules as microstructural features in the steel, which is more precise than a generic 'produces' predicate.

All three relations describe how the graphitization process changes or generates microstructural features in steels (altering existing microstructure or forming graphite nodules), so they belong to the same broader class of microstructural transformation relations.

Each relation expresses that a process (graphitization) modifies the state of a material by changing its microstructure or forming new microstructural constituents, fitting a broad modification/change-of-state dimension rather than simple association or identity.
